alt_statements.statement: As someone who’s spent a career in public education and believes in the common good, I think tech companies should be held to a standard similar to schools: they must be transparent, protect those who are most vulnerable, and never treat people as products without their informed consent. User data should be collected minimally, clearly explained in plain language, and used in ways that genuinely serve individuals and communities, not just corporate profit—ideally with strong public oversight and meaningful consequences when companies cross the line.

As someone who lives and breathes new gadgets and platforms, I’m not anti–data collection, but I believe tech companies have a serious responsibility to be radically transparent about what they’re taking and why. At a minimum, users should have clear, simple controls to opt in or out of data monetization, and no one’s personal information should be sold or shared without explicit, informed consent. Given how central digital life is to our democracy and basic dignity, there should be strong legal safeguards against abusive profiling and surveillance, and meaningful penalties when companies break the rules.

If a company’s going to make money off my data, the very least they owe me is clear, plain‑language consent and the option to say no without losing basic services. Where I come from, you don’t take more than you need, and that ought to apply to data too: collect the minimum, protect it like it’s hazardous waste, and never dump it on third parties without strict limits. These firms are reshaping our social and natural environment, so they should be legally and morally bound to treat user data as a public trust, not a gold mine to strip.

Tech companies have every right to make money, but if they’re using my data to do it, they owe me straight answers and real choices. I don’t want 50 pages of legal mumbo-jumbo—I want to know exactly what they’re collecting, how they’re selling it, and a simple way to say “no” without losing basic access. They should be held liable if they’re careless with people’s information, just like any other business that mishandles customer property. My data is mine first, their product second.

As someone who spends a lot of time online tracking bird migrations and using apps on the trail, I think tech companies have a serious responsibility to be transparent and honest about what data they collect and how they profit from it. Users should have clear, simple options to opt out of data sharing and to delete their information, not just pages of fine print nobody can realistically parse. I’m not against companies making money, but they shouldn’t treat our personal lives like open season—basic respect, consent, and strong privacy protections ought to be the standard, not an afterthought.

Tech companies deben tener la responsabilidad de ser claros y honestos sobre qué datos recogen, para qué los usan y con quién los comparten, en un lenguaje que cualquiera pueda entender, incluso si el inglés no es su primer idioma. Si van a ganar dinero con nuestra información, deberían darnos la opción de decir que no sin perder acceso a servicios esenciales, y deberían estar legalmente obligados a proteger esos datos para que no se usen contra nosotros, especialmente contra comunidades inmigrantes y familias trabajadoras. If they’re making money off our information, there should be clear consent, strong privacy protections, and real accountability when they misuse or lose that data. I also believe government regulations are necessary, because leaving it entirely to corporate goodwill has already shown us how quickly people’s rights and dignity can be sidelined in the pursuit of profit.

As someone who works hard in a hot kitchen every day, I don’t like the idea of tech companies quietly making money off people’s info like we’re just ingredients in their recipe. As someone who works long hours and still tries to be present for my kids, I don’t have time to read every privacy policy, so I think tech companies have a responsibility to make data practices truly transparent and easy to understand. And honestly, there should be stronger regulations to keep them from exploiting people—especially younger users—just because most of us are too busy or overwhelmed to keep up.

As someone who came to the U.S. and built a life here while juggling work, school, and raising a child, I think tech companies have a serious responsibility to treat our data with honesty and respect, not just as a way to make money. Because our data can reveal so much about our families, our politics, and even our faith, there should be strong legal protections and real consequences when companies misuse it, especially for vulnerable or immigrant communities. Tech companies have no business digging through every bit of our lives just to make a buck, and they sure as hell shouldn’t be doing it without our clear say‑so. Tech companies have a responsibility to be upfront and honest about what data they collect, how they use it, and who they share it with—no sneaky fine print. As someone who’s spent a lifetime caring for vulnerable people, I believe tech companies have a moral duty to treat our personal data with the same seriousness we give to medical privacy—clearly explaining what they collect, why, and getting real consent, not just burying it in fine print. As someone who values both personal privacy and the public good, I think tech companies have a responsibility to be completely transparent and honest about what data they collect, how they use it, and who they share it with. Tech companies have a responsibility to treat user data like a form of personal property, not just a resource to be mined for profit. Given how much of our lives now exist online, tech companies have a serious responsibility to treat user data like a public health and environmental resource—something to be protected, not exploited. Tech companies should treat users’ data like something very precious, not just a way to make quick money. As someone who loves technology and works on the ground in a regular job, I think tech companies have a responsibility to treat user data like something they’re borrowing, not owning.
